readingPart.reading:
aortainferior vena cavasuperior vena cava
arteriolemitral valvetricuspid valve
atriumpulmonary arteryventricle
capillarypulmonary veinvenule

questionContent.questionText:
1. valve that lies between the right atrium and the right ventricle [tricuspid valve]

2. smallest blood vessel [capillary]

3. carries oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart [pulmonary vein]

4. largest artery in the body [aorta]

5. brings oxygen-poor blood into the heart from the upper parts of the body [superior vena cava]

6. upper chamber of the heart [atrium]

7. carries oxygen-poor blood to the lungs from the heart [pulmonary artery]

8. small artery [arteriole]

9. valve that lies between the left atrium and the left ventricle [mitral valve]

10. brings blood from the lower half of the body to the heart [inferior vena cava]

11. small vein [venule]

12. lower chamber of the heart [ventricle]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed structures with the descriptions that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. right atrium

2. [tricuspid valve]

3. [right ventricle]

4. [pulmonary valve]

5. [pulmonary artery]

6. capillaries of the lung

7. [pulmonary veins]

8. [left atrium]

9. [mitral valve]

10. [left ventricle]

11. [aortic valve]

12. aorta

instructions.instructions: Trace the path of blood through the heart. Begin as the blood enters the right atrium from the venae cavae (and include the valves within the heart).

questionContent.questionText:
1. The pacemaker of the heart is the [sinoatrial node/SA node/sinoatrial (SA) node].

2. The sac-like membrane surrounding the heart is the [pericardium].

3. The wall of the heart between the right and the left atria is the [interatrial septum].

4. The relaxation phase of the heartbeat is called [diastole].

5. Specialized conductive tissue in the wall between the ventricles is the
[atrioventricular bundle/bundle of His].

6. The inner lining of the heart is the [endocardium].

7. The contractive phase of the heartbeat is called [systole].

8. A gas released as a metabolic product of catabolism is [carbon dioxide/CO2/carbon dioxide (CO2)].

9. Specialized conductive tissue at the base of the wall between the two upper heart chambers is the [atrioventricular node/AV node/atrioventricular (AV) node].

10. The inner lining of the pericardium, closely enveloping the heart, is the
[visceral pericardium].

11. An abnormal heart sound due to improper closure of heart valves is a 
[murmur].

12. The beat of the heart as felt through the walls of arteries is called the
[pulse].

1. hardening of arteries: arterio [sclerosis]

2. disease condition of heart muscle: cardio [myopathy]

3. enlargement of the heart: cardio [megaly]

4. inflammation of a vein: phleb [itis]

5. condition of rapid heartbeat: [tachy] cardia

6. condition of slow heartbeat: [brady] cardia

7. high levels of cholesterol in the blood: hyper [cholesterolemia]

8. surgical repair of a valve: valvulo [plasty]

9. condition of deficient oxygen: hyp [oxia]

10. pertaining to an upper heart chamber: [atri] al

11. narrowing of the mitral valve: mitral [stenosis]

12. breakdown of a clot: thrombo [lysis]

instructions.instructions: Complete the following terms using the given definitions.

readingPart.reading: bluish discoloration of the skin owing to deficient oxygen in the blood
incision of a vein
new connection between arteries
circulatory failure due to poor heart function
mass of yellowish plaque (fatty substance)
abnormal heart rhythm
instrument to measure blood pressure
instrument to listen to sounds within the chest
inflammation of the mitral valve
hardening of arteries with a yellowish, fatty substance (plaque)
narrowing of a vessel
widening of a vessel

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

readingPart.reading:
atrial septal defectendocarditismitral valve prolapse
coarctation of the aortafibrillationpatent ductus arteriosus
congestive heart failureflutterpericarditis
coronary artery diseasehypertensive heart diseasetetralogy of Fallot

questionContent.questionText:
1. inflammation of the inner lining of the heart [endocarditis]

2. rapid but regular atrial or ventricular contractions [flutter]

3. small hole between the upper heart chambers; congenital anomaly [atrial septal defect]

4. improper closure of the valve between the left atrium and ventricle during systole [mitral valve prolapse]

5. blockage of the arteries surrounding the heart leading to ischemia [coronary artery disease]

6. high blood pressure affecting the heart [hypertensive heart disease]

7. rapid, random, ineffectual, and irregular contractions of the heart [fibrillation]

8. inflammation of the sac surrounding the heart [pericarditis]

9. inability of the heart to pump its required amount of blood [congestive heart failure]

10. congenital malformation involving four separate heart defects [tetralogy of Fallot]

11. congenital narrowing of the large artery leading from the heart [coarctation of the aorta]

12. a duct between the aorta and the pulmonary artery, which normally closes soon after birth, remains open [patent ductus arteriosus]

instructions.instructions: Match the following pathologic conditions of the heart with their meanings below.

readingPart.reading: failure of proper conduction of impulses through the AV node to the atrioventricular bundle (bundle of His)
sudden unexpected stoppage of heart action
uncomfortable sensations in the chest associated with arrhythmias
battery-operated device that is placed in the chest and wired to send electrical current to the heart to establish a normal sinus rhythm
blockage of a vessel by a clot
chest pain resulting from insufficient oxygen being supplied to the heart muscle (ischemia)
area of necrosis (tissue death in the heart muscle; heart attack)
abnormal condition of death (dead tissue)
damage or death of tissue due to deprivation of oxygen
blood is held back from an area of the body
nitrate drug used in the treatment of angina
drug that treats arrhythmias and strengthens the heartbeat
abnormal sound (murmur) heard on auscultation
vibration felt on palpation of the chest
consequences of plaque rupture in coronary arteries; MI and unstable angina
scraping or grating noise on auscultation of heart; indicates pericarditis
clot formation in a large vein, usually in lower limb
device enabling ventricles to beat in synchrony; cardiac resynchronization therapy

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

readingPart.reading:
aneurysmessential hypertensionRaynaud disease
auscultationmurmurrheumatic heart disease
claudicationperipheral arterial diseasesecondary hypertension
embolipetechiaevegetations

questionContent.questionText:
1. lesions that form on heart valves after damage by infection [vegetations]

2. clots that travel to and suddenly block a blood vessel [emboli]

3. small, pinpoint hemorrhages [petechiae]

4. an extra heart sound, heard between normal beats and caused by a valvular defect or condition that disrupts the smooth flow of blood through the heart [murmur]

5. listening with a stethoscope [auscultation]

6. heart disease caused by rheumatic fever [rheumatic heart disease]

7. high blood pressure in arteries when the etiology is idiopathic [essential hypertension]

8. high blood pressure related to kidney disease [secondary hypertension]

9. episodes of pallor, numbness, and cyanosis in fingers and toes caused by a temporary  constriction of arterioles [Raynaud disease]

10. local widening of an artery [aneurysm]

11. pain, tension, and weakness in a limb after walking has begun [claudication]

12. blockage of arteries in the lower extremities; etiology is atherosclerosis [peripheral arterial disease]

instructions.instructions: Match the following terms with their descriptions.

prompt.text: 1. Types of drugs used to treat acute coronary syndromes include

readingPart.reading: beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, statins, aspirin, calcium channel blockers

prompt.text: 2. When damaged valves in veins fail to prevent the backflow of blood, a condition (swollen, twisted vein) that results is

readingPart.reading: varicose veins

prompt.text: 3. Swollen, twisted veins in the rectal region are called

readingPart.reading: hemorrhoids

prompt.text:
4. Name the four defects in tetralogy of Fallot from their descriptions:
    a. narrowing of the artery leading to the lungs from the heart

readingPart.reading: a. pulmonary artery stenosis

prompt.text: b. gap in the wall between the ventricles

readingPart.reading: b. ventricular septal defect

prompt.text: c. the large vessel leading from the left ventricle moves over the interventricular septum

readingPart.reading: c. shift of the aorta to the right

prompt.text: d. excessive development of the wall of the right lower heart chamber

readingPart.reading: d. hypertrophy of the right ventricle

angiography (arteriography)defibrillationlipid tests (profile)
cardiac biomarkersechocardiographylipoprotein electrophoresis
cardiac MRIelectrocardiographystress test
coronary artery bypass graftingendarterectomythallium 201 scan

questionContent.questionText:
1. surgical removal of plaque from the inner lining of an artery [endarterectomy]

2. application of brief electrical discharges across the chest to stop ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia [defibrillation]

3. measurement of levels of fatty substances (cholesterol and triglycerides) in the bloodstream [lipid tests (profile)]

4. measurement of the heart ’ s response to physical exertion (patient monitored while jogging on a treadmill) [stress test]

5. measurement of troponin-T and troponin-I after myocardial infarction [cardiac biomarkers]

6. injection of contrast into vessels and x-ray imaging [angiography]

7. recording of the electricity in the heart [electrocardiography]

8. intravenous injection of a radioactive substance and measurement of its accumulation in heart muscle [thallium 201 scan]

9. use of echoes from high-frequency sound waves to produce images of the heart [echocardiography]

10. separation of HDL and LDL from a blood sample [lipoprotein electrophoresis]

11. anastomosis of vessel grafts to existing coronary arteries to maintain blood supply to the myocardium [coronary artery bypass grafting]

12. beaming of magnetic waves at the heart to produce images of its structure [cardiac MRI]

instructions.instructions: Select from the list of cardiac tests and procedures to complete the definitions that follow.

readingPart.reading: Video equipment and a computer produce x-ray pictures of blood vessels by taking two pictures (without and with contrast) and subtracting the first image (without contrast) from the second.
A donor heart is transferred to a recipient.
Exercise tolerance test combined with a radioactive tracer scan.
An instrument that focuses sound waves on a blood vessel to measure blood flow.
A compact version of an electrocardiograph is worn during a 24-hour period to detect cardiac arrhythmias.
Treatment with drugs (streptokinase and tPA) to dissolve clots after a heart attack.
A heart-lung machine is used to divert blood from the heart and lungs during surgery. The machine oxygenates the blood and sends it back into the bloodstream.

A catheter (tube) is inserted into an artery or vein and threaded into the heart chambers. Contrast can be injected to take x-ray pictures, patterns of blood fl ow can be detected, and blood pressures can be measured.
A balloon-tipped catheter is inserted into a coronary artery to open the artery; stents are put in place.
Stents are expandable slotted tubes that are placed in arteries during PCI. They release polymers that prevent plaque from reforming.
Electron beams and CT identify calcium deposits in and around coronary arteries to diagnose CAD.
X-ray images of the heart and coronary arteries obtained using CT technology.

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings for the following terms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. AF [atrial fibrillation]

2. VT [ventricular tachycardia]

3. VF [ventricular fibrillation]

4. PVC [premature ventricular contraction]

5. PAC [premature atrial contraction]

instructions.instructions: Identify the following cardiac dysrhythmias from their abbreviations.

questionContent.questionText:
1. CHF [congestive heart failure]

2. VSD [ventricular septal defect]

3. MI [myocardial infarction]

4. PDA [patent ductus arteriosus]

5. MVP [mitral valve prolapse]

6. AS [aortic stenosis]

7. CAD [coronary artery disease]

8. ASD [atrial septal defect]

instructions.instructions: Identify the following abnormal cardiac conditions from their abbreviations.

readingPart.reading:
BNPECMOLDL
CRTETTLVAD
cTnI or cTnTETT-MIBIRFA
ECHOICDTEE

questionContent.questionText:
1. cardiac serum enzyme test for myocardial infarction [cTnI or cTnT]

2. booster pump implanted in the abdomen with a cannula leading to the heart as a “bridge to transplant” [LVAD]

3. ultrasound imaging of the heart using transducer within the esophagus [TEE]

4. device implanted in the chest that senses and corrects arrhythmias by shocking the heart [ICD]

5. catheter delivery of a high-frequency current to damage a small portion of the heart muscle and reverse an abnormal heart rhythm [RFA]

6. procedure to determine the heart ’ s response to physical exertion (stress) [ETT]

7. cardiac imaging using high-frequency sound waves pulsed through the chest wall and bounced off heart structures [ECHO]

8. radioactive test of heart function with stress test [ETT-MIBI]

9. technique using heart-lung machine to divert blood from the heart and lungs while the heart is being repaired [ECMO]

10. biventricular pacing to correct serious abnormal ventricular rhythms [CRT]

11. lipoprotein sample is measured [LDL]

12. brain chemical measured to identify patients at risk for complications after MI and with CHF [BNP]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed abbreviations for cardiac tests and procedures with the explanations/ descriptions that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. pertaining to the heart: [coron] ary

2. not a normal heart rhythm: arr [hythmia]

3. abnormal condition of blueness: [cyan] osis

4. relaxation phase of the heartbeat: [dias] tole

5. chest pain: [angina] pectoris

6. inflammation of a vein: [phleb] itis

7. widening of a vessel: vaso [dilation]

8. enlargement of the heart: cardio [megaly]

9. hardening of arteries with fatty plaque: [athero] sclerosis

10. swollen veins in the rectal region: [hemorrh] oids

instructions.instructions: Spell the term correctly from its definition.

readingPart.reading:
aneurysmorrhaphycatheter ablationpericardiocentesis
atherectomyembolectomySTEMI
BNP testendarterectomythrombolytic therapy
CABGPCIvalvotomy

questionContent.questionText:
1. incision of a heart valve [valvotomy]

2. removal of a clot that has traveled into a blood vessel and suddenly caused occlusion [embolectomy]

3. coronary artery bypass grafting (to relieve ischemia) [CABG]

4. surgical puncture to remove fluid from the pericardial space [pericardiocentesis]

5. insertion of a balloon-tipped catheter and stents into a coronary artery [PCI]

6. removal of the inner lining of an artery to make it wider [endarterectomy]

7. suture (repair) of a ballooned-out portion of an artery [aneurysmorrhaphy]

8. removal of plaque from an artery [atherectomy]

9. type of acute coronary syndrome [STEMI]

10. use of streptokinase and tPA to dissolve clots [thrombolytic therapy]

11. brief delivery of radiofrequency energy to destroy areas of heart tissue for treating arrhythmias [catheter ablation]

12. measures a peptide elevated in patients with heart failure [BNP test]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed terms for cardiovascular procedures with the meanings/descriptions that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Bill was having pain in his chest that radiated up his neck and down his arm. He called his family physician, who thought Bill should report to the local hospital’s emergency department (ED) immediately. The first test performed in the ED was a/an [ECG/stress test/CABG].

2. Dr. Kelly explained to the family that their observation of the bluish color of baby Charles’s skin helped her make the diagnosis of a/an [septal/thrombotic/aneurysmal] defect in the baby ’s heart, which needed immediate attention.

3. Mr. Duggan had a fever of unknown origin. When the doctors completed an echocardiogram and saw vegetations on his mitral valve, they suspected [bacterial endocarditis/hypertensive heart disease/angina].

4. Claudia’s fingers turned white or bluish whenever she went out into the cold or became stressed. Her physician thought it might be wise to evaluate her for [Raynaud’s/varicose veins/intermittent claudication].

5. Daisy’s heart felt as if it was skipping beats every time she drank coffee. Her physician suggested that she wear a/an [Holter monitor/LVAD/CABG] for 24 hours to assess the nature of the arrhythmia.

6. Paola’s father and grandfather died of heart attacks. Her physician tells her that she has inherited a tendency to accumulate fats in her bloodstream. Blood tests reveal high levels of [lipids/enzymes/nitroglycerin]. Discussing her family history with her [cardiologist/gynecologist/hematologist] , she understands that she has familial [hypercholesterolemia/hypocholesterolemia/cardiomyopathy].

7. While exercising, Bernard experienced a pain (cramp) in his calf muscle. The pain disappeared when he was resting. After performing [Doppler ultrasound/Holter monitoring/echocardiography] on his leg to assess blood flow, Dr. Shaw found [stenosis/fibrillation/endocarditis] , indicating poor circulation. She recommended a daily exercise program, low-fat diet, careful foot care, and antiplatelet drug therapy to treat Bernard’s intermittent [claudication/palpitations/hypertension] .

8. Carol noticed that her 6-week-old son Louis had a slightly bluish or [cyanotic/jaundiced/diastolic] coloration to his skin. She consulted a pediatric [cardiologist/dermatologist/hematologist] , who performed [echocardiography/PET scan/endarterectomy] and diagnosed Louis’s condition as [tetralogy of Fallot/endocarditis/congestive heart disease].

9. Seventy-eight-year-old John Smith has had coronary artery disease and high blood pressure for the past 10 years. His history included an acute heart attack, or [MI/PDA/CABG] . He often was tired and complained of [dyspnea/nausea/migraine headaches] and swelling in his ankles. His physician diagnosed his condition as [congestive heart failure/aortic aneurysm/congenital heart disease] and recommended restricted salt intake, diuretics, and an [ACE inhibitor/antibiotic/analgesic].

10. Sarah had a routine checkup that included [auscultation/vasoconstriction/vasodilation] of her chest with a [stethoscope/catheter/stent] to listen to her heart. Her physician noticed a midsystolic murmur characteristic of [MVP/DVT/LDL]. An echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis.

instructions.instructions: Select the correct terms that best complete each sentence.
